trial_identification.studytitle: Improving neurobehavioural development in preterm infants
trial_identification.scientifictitle: 'Environmental intervention, using parent sensitivity training, to improve neurobehavioural development in preterm infants: A randomised controlled trial'.

conditions.healthcondition: Potential neurobehavioural and neurodevelopmental deficits associated with premature birth

interventions.interventions: Intensive parent sensitivity training in first 12 weeks following premature birth aimed at reducing infant stress.
interventions.comparator: Control Group mothers receive one psycho-educational session concerning coping with stress and copies of an educational booklet

primaryOutcome.outcome: Neurobehavioural development as assessed by the Ages & Stages Questionnaire
Neurobehavioural development as assessed by the Bayley Scales of Infant Development (III) and the Child Behavior Checklist
Neurobehavioural development as assessed by the Short Temperament Scales
The Neonatal Medical Index computed from hospital records

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Mothers of singleton or twin infants born at less than or equal to 30 weeks gestational age will be included.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Families living outside a 100km radius of Melbourne, those with insufficient English, and those whose infants have a congenital abnormality will be excluded. Any mothers whose young age precludes them from giving fully informed consent will also be excluded.

trial_design.concealment: Central administration of a coded, blinded, independently pre-generated allocation schedule operated via a sytem of sealed, numbered, opaque, tamper-evident envelopes.
trial_design.sequence: Variable-length permuted blocks, computer-generated random sequence, stratified with respect to study site and with respect to twin versus singleton families

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Parent-Infant Research Institute, Austin Health, Melbourne

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To date, intervention foci to improve neurobehavioural outcomes in preterm infants have been primarily medical. The intervention developed for this study is based on the observation of severe dysregulation in premature infants and the potential of sensitive maternal-infant interaction to modulate the damaging effects of stress on infants' general and brain development. In essence we aim to train mothers to be therapists to their own hospitalised preterm infant. The development of infants of intervention and control mothers will be assessed and compared at several ages until 24 months corrected age.
